data.subject: FINE
data.title: Studio Fundamentals
data.description: This course introduces the basic principles of drawing as it relates to concepts of 2D, 3D, and time-based media, through a series of drawing exercises and projects.
data.notes: [Note: This course is primarily for students who are considering a Fine Arts studio academic plan. It includes a significant component of mandatory life drawing from the nude model. Please see the Fine Arts academic plans concerning admission to upper-level studio courses.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art History and Visual Culture
data.description: This course takes a case study approach to examining the role of the art object as a means of communication within the history of visual culture. Particular attention will also be paid to the unique properties of a range of diverse media, both traditional and new.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: World Cinema and Visual Culture
data.description: Introduction to film analysis via national cinemas and their worldwide reception, taking into account the role of new technologies. This course acknowledges not only the importance of multiple languages and cultures on the planet today but also the rapidly growing international contexts, complicated chains of production and distribution, and vastly different cultures of spectatorship.
data.notes: [Note: All films will be shown with subtitles; no second language expertise is required.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Modern Art, 1874-1945
data.description: A study of the culture of Europe and North America from 1874 (Impressionism) to 1945 (Nazi propaganda) with particular focus on the visual arts. Topics such as 'primitivism', Cubism, 'abstraction', artists' reactions to calamitous world events such as World War I, and various methodologies, including semiotic and Marxist analyses, will be explored through reading and writing assignments.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Introduction to Digital Imaging
data.description: This online course is an introduction to current imaging software that students use to explore contemporary topics through digital imaging. This course is taught from a Fine Arts perspective.
data.antirequisites: FINE 204 section 081 (online) taken fall 2011 or winter 2012
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Not open to students who have completed FINE/GBDA 228 or FINE/GBDA 229.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Appreciation and Expression
data.description: The course delivers an introduction to a variety of basic techniques and concepts relevant to contemporary 2D, 3D, and digital art practices, through a series of structured studio exercises and assignments.
data.prerequisites: Not open to Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: Formerly FINE 200. Studio Course. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times. This course cannot be used to fulfil Fine Arts Studios degree requirements.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Painting
data.description: This course explores issues of representation and abstraction, with a focus on painting and colour theory and practice.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Studio Practice
data.description: This course consists of topics in studio practice. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A Fine Arts students; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Art History
data.description: This course consists of topics in art history. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Film Studies
data.description: This course consists of topics in film studies. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Modern Art, 1940-1970
data.description: This course explores two dominant themes in art of the mid-twentieth century: Abstract Expressionism and Pop Art, and their variants in the United States, Canada, and Europe.
data.prerequisites: FINE 112.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art, 1780-1875
data.description: A study of art and architecture in European and American culture between c. 1780 and c. 1875. Some of the pertinent themes discussed include: art and revolutions; art and the Industrial Revolution; the rise of landscape painting; the urban environment; the exotic; and the erotic. Cross-cultural influences and the complex relationship between the traditional and the 'modern' are particularly emphasized.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Renaissance Art, 1300-1500
data.description: An examination of the art of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries in Europe. Amongst the many themes that will be explored in this course are: mediums (including exploitation of oil paint); scientific perspective; humanism; court structures; art and mercantile sectors; and prominent collectors.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art of the 16th Century in Europe
data.description: Some of the finest works of art in the western world were produced and some of the most successful artists flourished in this tumultuous century that saw the split in the western Christian Church and the continued rise of extraordinarily powerful court families and monarchs. This course will examine these works of art and the artists against this backdrop. Arranged according to patrons, the course also examines particular stylistic trends (Mannerism, the persistence of the Gothic, etc.) as well as other pertinent issues such as collecting; the writing of art history; the teaching of art; and the role of the artist in society.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Visual Culture of Medieval Europe
data.description: This course explores the visual culture of medieval Europe from the 4th century to the 13th century. The primary focus of this course is the dynamic intersection of cultures and faiths with particular emphasis on emergent and evolving Christianity, Islam, and Judaism, as expressed in architecture, sculpture, manuscripts, metalwork, textiles, and more.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art of the 17th Century in Europe
data.description: Art of the 17th Century. This course focuses on art produced in Italy, Spain, France, England and the Netherlands in the 17th century. Various types of art (history painting, portraiture, still life, etc.) and architecture (churches, palaces, city homes, etc.) are discussed in relation to the primary political, religious and societal concerns that characterize the different geographical regions.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in First Nations' Visual Culture
data.description: A study of historical and contemporary aspects of First Nations' visual culture. The particular emphasis will vary according to the specialization and interests of the instructor.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Oil Painting
data.description: Various technical methodologies of oil painting and pictorial composition are developed in this course through a series of explorations in observation and abstraction. The plurality of approaches available to painters today is set within a contemporary critical context.
data.prerequisites: FINE 202
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Acrylic and Mixed Media
data.description: This course takes a materially specific approach to painting projects involving acrylic and mixed media. Emphasis is placed on creative problem solving in the context of contemporary art practice.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Principles of Sculpture
data.description: This studio course is designed to introduce students to a variety of traditional and contemporary approaches, materials, processes, and conceptual concerns related to working in sculpture. Through demonstrations, presentations, critiques, and discussions, students gain expertise and develop a sculptural vocabulary.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100, or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Methods and Materials of Sculpture
data.description: This studio course emphasizes practical applications of traditional and contemporary materials, processes, and conceptual concerns.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Clay Studies
data.description: Using a variety of clay bodies and firing techniques, students will explore figurative and abstract sculptural concepts, to develop a working knowledge of clay as a sculptural medium.
data.prerequisites: FINE 120, 121; Portfolio Review milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Expressive Drawing
data.description: Expressive drawing techniques are emphasized through study with the life model. Conceptual drawing projects provide the student with the opportunity to produce bodies of work.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course includes a significant component of mandatory life drawing from the nude model.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Observational Drawing
data.description: Observational techniques are used to develop an understanding of the principles and concepts of drawing practice.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course includes a significant component of mandatory life drawing from the nude model.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Introduction to Printmaking A
data.description: Introduction to a variety of printmaking processes.
data.prerequisites: FINE 120, 121; Portfolio Review milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Experimental Drawing
data.description: Experimental drawing is a course for those who wish to challenge their ideas about drawing and image making. An emphasis will be placed on contemporary approaches to drawing and the development of individual forms of expression.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course includes a significant component of mandatory life drawing from the nude model.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Photography
data.description: Students will explore black and white analogue (film) photography techniques and history, taught through a series of exercises, with an emphasis on fine arts practice.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Formerly FINE 228E. Studio course. Students are required to own or have access to a fully manual 35mm film camera.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Digital Imaging
data.description: In this course students are introduced to digital tools through a series of exercises and assignments that cultivate both artistic expression and technical skill. Topics include photography, design, typography, and critical and cultural theory taught from a fine art perspective.
data.prerequisites: Fine 100 or 130; Portfolio Review Milestone.
data.antirequisites: DAC 203/301/ENGL 304; FINE 228/GBDA 228 taken prior to Fall 2017
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Previous experience with digital image manipulation is useful.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Hybrid Digital Media
data.description: This course uses a variety of digital software to explore the place of digital technology in contemporary art practice. Group discussions and individual assignments are major components of this course.
data.prerequisites: Fine 100 or 130; Portfolio Review Milestone.
data.antirequisites: DAC 203/301/ENGL 304; FINE 229/GBDA 229 taken prior to Fall 2017
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Introduction to Printmaking A
data.description: Introduction to a variety of printmaking processes.
data.prerequisites: FINE 120, 121; Portfolio Review milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Mixed Multiples
data.description: The course examines the field of traditional printmaking which has expanded to include new and emerging photo-based technologies and ideas that focus on the concept of the multiple.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Video and Sound
data.description: This course explores time-based media within a contemporary art context focusing on video and sound. Students learn how to record and edit material through a series of short self-directed projects. Approaches range from stop-motion animation, live-action, and performance to sound and installation.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Fine Arts Experiential Learning
data.description: This course enables Fine Arts students to gain valuable work experience within an art-related environment. Collaboration between students, professional artists, and art institutions creates a unique learning experience that complements the student's program of study.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A Fine Arts students; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Graded on a credit/no credit basis. A minor field trip fee may apply. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: History of Visual Media to 1910
data.description: This course provides a chronological and thematic overview of the history of visual media examining technologies such as the printing press, photography, early cinema, and the representation of perspective.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: History of Film and Visual Media from 1900 to Today
data.description: The course provides a chronological and thematic overview of the history of visual media in Modernity and Postmodernity. It starts at the beginning of the 20th century with the rise of cinema and ends with discussion of the digital age.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Religion in Popular Film
data.description: This course examines how religion has been a central concern and inspiration for filmmakers and how popular films have informed and shaped our understanding of religion.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies Course. This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in Religion and Film
data.description: Each semester, this course focuses on a specific genre or theme to explore the complex relationship between cinema and religion. Topics may include science fiction, fantasy, horror, comedy, and documentary films.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies course. This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors. This course is repeatable up to five times, subject to different content.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Film as Social Criticism
data.description: Cinema as 'prophetic voice', exploring the films of various directors as they pertain to selected themes which include technology and dehumanization, individual and collective goals, social realities and dreams, and the quest for individual and cultural identity.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Experimental Film
data.description: The course introduces students to the history, methodologies, theories, and aesthetics of non-narrative experimental film with a focus on intersections between film and visual and performing arts.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Video, New Media & the Digital Turn
data.description: This course analyzes the shift in visual practices of the 20th century transformed by the arrival of various digital technologies. An emphasis is placed on the increasing interdisciplinarity of new media, as well as their multi-sensory nature.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Global Queer Cinema
data.description: This course introduces the varied production of world-wide gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender cinema. Inquiry will focus on how queer cinematic production serves as a vehicle for documentation and education, aesthetic and sexual experimentation, as well as cultural export and self-inquiry.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Ceramics: Studies in Material Practice
data.description: Students will explore ceramic material practice as a method for creative expression. The course will focus on visual and conceptual problem solving, while acquiring technical skills and knowledge of ceramic material. The assignments will incorporate hand building, mold making, surface treatments, and glazing techniques.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100, or FINE 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Clay Studies
data.description: Using a variety of clay bodies and firing techniques, students will explore figurative and abstract sculptural concepts, to develop a working knowledge of clay as a sculptural medium.
data.prerequisites: FINE 120, 121; Portfolio Review milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Figure and Anatomy
data.description: Students will explore the practice of drawing through the thorough study of the human figure and anatomy. Through a series of studio projects in diverse and mixed media, students will confront the dual challenges of careful observation and personal expression.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course includes a significant component of mandatory life drawing from the nude model and from human cadavers.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art and Gender
data.description: A study of selected themes dealing with gender in the history of art: e.g., the representation of the human body; portrayal of mythological, spiritual and allegorical figures; professional and amateur artists and their status within societies; etc.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Canadian Art from the 17th Century to 1940
data.description: This course examines art in Canada from the beginning of the European settlement in the seventeenth century to the Group of Seven and the Canadian Group of Painters. Some of the issues that will be investigated include the perception of Canada from abroad, the "new world", nation and nationhood, and the invention and appropriation of culture.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Fine Arts Abroad
data.description: This is a topics course that provides students with an introduction to and a familiarity with the art and culture of a particular destination. Working in the field with landscape, cityscape, and monuments of art, students will employ a variety of media to develop techniques for visual reportage, documentation, note-taking, and journal-keeping. Individual aesthetic responses to a wide range of subject matter will be encouraged.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121
data.notes: [Note: Information about current offerings can be obtained from the Department. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times. A field trip fee will apply.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Fine Arts Abroad
data.description: Working in the field with landscape, cityscape, and monuments of art, students will employ a variety of media to develop techniques for visual reportage, documentation, note-taking, and journal-keeping. Individual aesthetic responses to a wide range of subject matter will be encouraged.
data.prerequisites: At least 75% in FINE 293
data.notes: [Note: Information about current offerings can be obtained from the Department. This course is repeatable up to four times, subject to different content.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Studio Practice
data.description: This course provides Fine Arts students with an opportunity to study a range of topics that will expand, explore, and refine personal areas of interest in studio practice. Students will be required to undertake a range of classroom assignments in addition to working independently on an area of focus.
data.prerequisites: FINE 319; At least four 200-level FINE studio courses; Level at least 3A
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Studio Practice
data.description: This is an advanced fine arts studio course with an emphasis on development of the student's individual and independent research interests. Students will be guided by faculty through one-on-one critiques as well as open forums and group critiques.
data.prerequisites: FINE 300; Level at least 3B Honours Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Analysis and Research
data.description: This course hones critical analysis skills and develops research practices (by exploring artists, materials, techniques, readings, etc.) that will enhance the student's knowledge of contemporary art practice, as well as equiping students to articulate their area of interest within contemporary art. Gallery visits and artists' talks are components of this course.
data.prerequisites: FINE 319; Level at least 3A Honours Fine Arts students.
data.notes: [Note: A field trip fee of $100 may be required.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Art History Research
data.description: Students work with assigned faculty in a reading seminar environment to explore aspects of art history and theory that are relevant to each student's areas of interest. Gallery visits are a component of this course.
data.prerequisites: FINE 319; Level at least 3B Honours Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: A field trip fee of $100 may be required.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Studio Practice
data.description: This course consists of topics in studio practice. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Art History
data.description: This course consists of topics in art history. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Film Studies
data.description: This course consists of topics in film studies. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Contemporary Art
data.description: A survey of contemporary international art movements with emphasis on work since 1970. Readings in contemporary criticism and gallery visits are an integral part of the course.
data.prerequisites: VCULT/FINE 101 or FINE 110; FINE 112, 209
data.notes: [Note: Art History course. To be taken in 2B.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics Course in Museums, Galleries, Curatorship
data.description: Often taught by the University of Waterloo Curator, this course explores a range of topics dealing with museums, galleries, and curatorial practices. Field visits may be a required component of this course.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: A field trip fee of up to $100 may be required. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art of the 18th Century in Europe
data.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the culture of eighteenth century Europe. Particular attention is paid to France and Britain but these countries are discussed within the wider context of Europe and, at times, much of the world. By looking at the art, artists, patrons and collectors, some of the issues that will be discussed include cosmopolitanism, nationalism, empire-building, "taste", consumerism and women in society.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2B Fine Arts or History or by permission of instructor.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: History of Art Academies
data.description: This course examines the history of the institutionalization of the teaching of art. The course is organized as a series of 'case studies' dealing with various formal academies of art and less formal gatherings of artists from the Renaissance to the twentieth century. The aims of the course are to analyze why these institutions were formed, how they were organized, what were their mandates, and what was their status in their contemporary worlds. Some of the themes that will be investigated throughout the course include: art in the service of power and politics, the status of the artist, the ideal human form, the classical and medieval traditions, the impact of the avant-garde, the conflict with authority, and the academy as community.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Fine Arts or History or by permission of instructor
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Philosophy of Art
data.description: What is art? What is beauty? What do the two have to do with each other? This course introduces students to some fundamental issues in the philosophy of art, and to a variety of philosophical views on these issues.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Fine Arts Experiential Learning
data.description: This course enables Fine Arts students to gain valuable work experience within an art-related environment. Collaboration between students, professional artists, and art institutions creates a unique learning experience that complements the student's program of study.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Fine Arts majors
data.notes: [Note: Graded on a credit/no credit basis. A minor field trip fee may apply. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Fine Arts Internship
data.description: This experiential learning course is intended to enable Fine Arts students to gain valuable work experience within an art related environment. The course is designed to complement the student's academic program by providing an opportunity for the practical application of skills and concepts.
data.prerequisites: FINE 343; Fine Arts majors
data.notes: [Note: Graded on a credit/no credit basis. A minor field trip fee may apply.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in German Film
data.description: Selected topics in German film.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: German Film Classics
data.description: Masterpieces of German film from the silent era to present.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: German Filmmakers in Hollywood
data.description: An examination of the work of filmmakers who have made a mark in both European and American cinema.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: German and Russian Film Pioneers
data.description: An examination of early German and Russian cinema, and the way these two film industries influenced each other. Influential theories of film from the period will also be studied.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: International Comics and Animation Film
data.description: This course will examine the interconnections of comics (graphic novels, manga, etc.) and animated film, forms of visual communication particular to the 20th and 21st centuries, in the historical and social contexts of various national traditions.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Fine Arts Abroad
data.description: This is a topics course that provides students with an introduction to and a familiarity with the arts and culture of a particular destination. Working in the field with landscape, cityscape, and monuments of art, students will employ a variety of media to develop techniques for visual reportage, documentation, note-taking, and journal-keeping. Individual aesthetic responses to a wide range of subject matter will be encouraged.
data.notes:
[Note: Information about current offerings can be obtained from the Department. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times. A significant field trip fee will
apply.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Methods in the History of Art
data.description: Students will explore a variety of research tools such as stylistic analyses, iconographical interpretations, provenance studies, and readings in art historiography.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3A Honours or Four-year General Art History majors
data.notes: [Note: Formerly FINE 390A]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Directed Study
data.description: This course is intended to help Fine Arts students make the transition from art school to professional practice by providing an opportunity to examine their own practice within the larger context of the professional art world.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: A field trip fee of $100 may be required.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Studio Practice
data.description: This course consists of topics in studio practice. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Art History
data.description: This course consists of topics in art history. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in Film Studies
data.description: This course consists of topics in film studies. The topics can change from term to term.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior Seminar in Film Concepts
data.description: This senior seminar combines discussion of methodology and film theory with film screenings.
data.notes: [Note: Film studies course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior Seminar in Film Concepts 2
data.description: Film screenings.
data.notes: [Note: Film studies course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Intensive Studio Specialization 1
data.description: This course is for students who wish to be practicing artists and who are enrolled in the Intensive Studio Specialization. The course involves an intensive exploration and development of individual studio research through practice, resulting in the production of a significant body of work. Students will be guided by the work of relevant artists, as well as critiques by faculty members, graduate students, visiting artists, and fellow students. Submitted work will be evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts faculty.
data.prerequisites: A grade of 75% in each of FINE 300, 301, 302, 303; a cumulative Fine Arts average of 75%; Level at least 4A Honours Fine Arts Studio.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Admission by portfolio review.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Intensive Studio Specialization 2
data.description: This course is for students who wish to be practicing artists, and who are enrolled in the Intensive Studio Specialization plan. Students will develop strategies for independent studio research, and complete a body of work supported and complemented by appropriate documentation. Submitted studio work will be evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts Faculty.
data.prerequisites: FINE 472.
data.notes: [Note: This is a required course for all students in Fine Arts Honours Studio specialization. All students need to have completed all second- and third-year courses in their desired area of concentration (e.g. students wishing to concentrate on painting need to have successfully completed FINE 220, 221, 320 and 321, as well as FINE 472.)]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Studio Practicum 1
data.description: This course provides Fine Arts students with an opportunity to study a range of topics that will explore, expand, and refine personal areas of interest in studio practice. Students will be required to undertake a range of classroom assignments in addition to working independently on an area of focus. Submitted studio work will be evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts Faculty.
data.prerequisites: At least 1.0 unit of 300-level FINE studio courses; Level at least 4A Honours Studio Practice
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course may be taken only as an elective after a student has completed 15.0 units and has taken all the courses available in the area related to the independent course (i.e. painting, drawing, printmaking, sculpture or electronic imaging courses).]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Studio Practicum 2
data.description: Students will research and execute a series of self-directed projects, addressing historical precedents in the context of the concerns of contemporary art practice, and supported and complemented by appropriate documentation. Submitted studio work will be evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts Faculty.
data.prerequisites: FINE 474
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course may be taken only as an elective after a student has completed 15.0 units and has taken all the courses available in the area related to the independent course (i.e. painting, drawing, printmaking, sculpture or electronic imaging courses).]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Film Studies Thesis 1
data.description: Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on a research thesis in film studies. The work in this course will be evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts faculty members.
data.prerequisites: FINE 470, 471; Level at least 4A Film Studies Students only.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Film Studies Thesis 2
data.description: A continuation of FINE 490.
data.prerequisites: FINE 490

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior General Film Studies Project
data.description: Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on an advanced research project in film studies. The course is evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts faculty members.
data.prerequisites: FINE 470, 471; Level at least 4A General Film Studies students only.
data.notes: [Note: Formerly FINE 490A]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior General Art History Project
data.description: Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on an advanced project in art history. A committee of Fine Arts faculty members participates in the evaluation process.
data.prerequisites: FINE 396.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Art History Thesis 1
data.description: Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on an advanced research project in art history, subject to the approval of the Fine Arts Department. The student is expected to present his/her research findings to members of the faculty at the end of the term. The course is evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts faculty members.
data.prerequisites: FINE 396; Honours Art History.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Art History Thesis 2
data.description: Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on an advanced research project in art history. This project may be related to the project completed for FINE 496. The course is evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts faculty members.
data.prerequisites: FINE 496; Honours Art History students

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Studio 1 (Part-Time)
data.description: This course consists of directed individual studio work in the student's chosen area of concentration, as indicated in their original statement of intention.  Regular critiques and discussions will be scheduled by the Graduate Committee.  Open to Fine Arts part-time graduate students only.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Studio 1 (Part-time)
data.description: This course consists of directed individual studio work in the student's chosen area of concentration, as indicated in their original statement of intention.  Regular critiques and discussions will be scheduled by the Graduate Committee.  Open to Fine Arts part-time graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: FINE 670A

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Summer Studies 1 (Part-time)
data.description: Students will carry out independent studio work under the supervision of Fine Arts faculty members.  Work done during this course will be exhibited early in the Fall term.  Open to part-time Fine Arts graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: FINE 670B

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Studio 2 (Part-Time)
data.description: This course consists of directed individual studio work in the student's chosen area of concentration, as indicated in their original statement of intention.  Regular critiques and discussions will be scheduled by the Graduate Committee.  Open to Fine Arts part-time graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: FINE 671

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Studio 2 (Part-Time)
data.description: This course consists of directed individual studio work in the student's chosen area of concentration, as indicated in their original statement of intention.  Regular critiques and discussions will be scheduled by the Graduate Committee.  Open to Fine Arts part-time graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: FINE 671 and FINE 672A

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Summer Studio 2 (Part-Time)
data.description: Students will carry out independent studio work under the supervision of Fine Arts faculty members.  Work done during this course will be exhibited early in the Fall term.  Open to part-time Fine Arts graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: FINE 672B

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Studio 3 (Part-time)
data.description: This course consists of directed individual studio work in the student's chosen area of concentration, as indicated in their original statement of intention.  Regular critiques and discussions will be shcedule by the Graduate Committee.  Open to Fine Arts part-time graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: FINE 673

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Issues in Contemporary Art 1
data.description: A seminar course in which the various issues, motives and concerns of contemporary art will be presented and discussed. In addition to lectures on contemporary art, visiting artists and critics will speak on various aspects of the field, and participate in group discussions. Students will carry out research on individual topics and will make an extended presentation of their findings towards the end of the term. Open to Fine Arts graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: Open to Fine Arts graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Issues in Contemporary Art 2
data.description: A continuation of FINE 680. The research begun in FINE 680 will be continued in greater depth and consolidated in a major written paper.  Open to Fine Arts graduate students only. Prerequisite: FINE 680.
data.prerequisites: FINE 680. Open to Fine Arts graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Senior Seminar 1
data.description: This course will meet coterminously with FINE 680 . Students at this level will help to organize parts of the course and will serve as commentators and respondents for the critiques and presentations of the students in FINE 680.  Open to Fine Arts graduate students only. Prerequisite: FINE 680, 681.
data.prerequisites: FINE 680 and 681. Open to Fine Arts graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Senior Seminar 2
data.description: This course is a continuation of FINE 682.  Open to Fine Arts graduate students only. Prerequisite: FINE 682.
data.prerequisites: FINE 682. Open to Fine Art graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Studio 1
data.description: This course consists of directed individual studio work in the student's chosen area of concentration, as indicated in their original statement of intention. Appropriate studio space will be provided for all students enroled in this course, and regular critiques and discussions will be scheduled by the First Year Graduate Committee.  Open to Fine Arts graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: Open to Fine Arts graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Studio 2
data.description: A continuation of FINE 690 ; directed individual studio work in the student's chosen area of concentration.  Open to Fine Arts graduate students only. Prerequisite: FINE 690.
data.prerequisites: FINE 690. Open to Fine Art graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Graduate Summer Studio
data.description: Students will carry out independent studio work under the supervision of Fine Arts faculty members. During half of the term, students may serve as interns in the studios of professional artists, under the terms of the Keith and Win Shantz Summer Internship Program. Work done during this course will be exhibited early in the Fall term.  Open to Fine Arts graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: Open to Fine Arts graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in Art History and Criticism
data.description: Reading courses in art history and criticism, to be arranged subject to Fine Arts Department approval. Open to Fine Arts graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: Open to Fine Arts graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Selected Subjects in Studio Art
data.description: Studio practice courses in various media, to be arranged subject to Fine Arts Department approval. Open to Fine Arts graduate students only.
data.prerequisites: Open to Fine Arts graduate students only

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in German Film
data.description: Selected topics in German film.
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: German Film Classics
data.description: Masterpieces of German film from the silent era to present.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: German Filmmakers in Hollywood
data.description: An examination of the work of filmmakers who have made a mark in both European and American cinema.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: German and Russian Film Pioneers
data.description: An examination of early German and Russian cinema, and the way these two film industries influenced each other. Influential theories of film from the period will also be studied.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Philosophy of Art
data.description: What is art? What is beauty? What do the two have to do with each other? This course introduces students to some fundamental issues in the philosophy of art, and to a variety of philosophical views on these issues.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A

data.subject: FINE
data.title: German and Russian Film Pioneers
data.description: An examination of early German and Russian cinema, and the way these two film industries influenced each other. Influential theories of film from the period will also be studied.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2A
data.notes: [Note: Taught in English.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Religion in Popular Film
data.description: This course examines how religion has been a central concern and inspiration for filmmakers and how popular films have informed and shaped our understanding of religion.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies Course. This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in Religion and Film
data.description: Each semester, this course focuses on a specific genre or theme to explore the complex relationship between cinema and religion. Topics may include science fiction, fantasy, horror, comedy, and documentary films.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies course. This course fulfils an Area 3B requirement for Religious Studies majors. This course is repeatable up to five times, subject to different content.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: World Cinema and Visual Culture
data.description: Introduction to film analysis via national cinemas and their worldwide reception, taking into account the role of new technologies. This course acknowledges not only the importance of multiple languages and cultures on the planet today but also the rapidly growing international contexts, complicated chains of production and distribution, and vastly different cultures of spectatorship.
data.notes: [Note: All films will be shown with subtitles; no second language expertise is required.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art History and Visual Culture
data.description: This course takes a case study approach to examining the role of the art object as a means of communication within the history of visual culture. Particular attention will also be paid to the unique properties of a range of diverse media, both traditional and new.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Global Queer Cinema
data.description: This course introduces the varied production of world-wide gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender cinema. Inquiry will focus on how queer cinematic production serves as a vehicle for documentation and education, aesthetic and sexual experimentation, as well as cultural export and self-inquiry.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Introduction to Art History
data.description: This course is not intended to be a chronological survey of the history of art. Rather, it is an introduction to art and to art in history. The primary aims of the course are: to develop the visual skills and acquire the vocabulary needed to analyze a work of art; to examine works of art according to techniques and materials (e.g. how the 'Mona Lisa' was executed); and to examine works of art within the context in which they were created. Modes of artistic education and the exhibition of art objects are also explored. Examples of art are drawn from various time periods and cultures. A field trip fee of $10-$15 may be required.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Fundamentals of Visual Art 1
data.description: An introduction to the fundamental principles and concepts of visual art through a series of exercises using a variety of materials.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course is primarily for students who are considering a specialization in Fine Arts. It includes a significant component of mandatory work - drawing, painting, other media - from the life model. Please see the Fine Arts Academic plans concerning admission to upper level studio courses.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Fundamentals of Visual Art 2
data.description: A continuation of FINE 120 with further exploration of the fundamental principles and concepts of visual art.
data.prerequisites: FINE 120
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course is primarily for students who are considering a specialization in Fine Arts. Please see the Fine Arts Academic plans concerning admission to upper level studio courses.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Appreciation and Expression
data.description: The course delivers an introduction to a variety of basic techniques and concepts relevant to contemporary 2D, 3D, and digital art practices, through a series of structured studio exercises and assignments.
data.prerequisites: Not open to Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: Formerly FINE 200. Studio Course. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of two times. This course cannot be used to fulfil Fine Arts Studios degree requirements.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Intermediate Printmaking B
data.description: Exploration of printmaking as a vehicle for creative expression.
data.prerequisites: FINE 120, 121, 226A; Portfolio Review milestone
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in Printmaking
data.description: An investigation into a variety of experimental, non-traditional printmaking techniques.
data.prerequisites: FINE 226A, 226B
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Photography
data.description: Students will explore black and white analogue (film) photography techniques and history, taught through a series of exercises, with an emphasis on fine arts practice.
data.prerequisites: FINE 100 or 120 and 121; Portfolio Review Milestone
data.notes: [Note: Formerly FINE 228E. Studio course. Students are required to own or have access to a fully manual 35mm film camera.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: The study of art in context including visiting artists' lectures, gallery and museum exhibitions and field trips. Specific course content term-by-term will be structured around the schedule of events in the department and the region.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: See FINE 248A for course description.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: The study of art in context including visiting artists' lectures, gallery and museum exhibitions and field trips. Specific course content term-by-term will be structured around the schedule of events in the department and the region. Students will be required to prepare written reports and visual documents.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: See FINE 249A for course description.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Selected Subjects in Fine Arts
data.description: A variety of art history topics taught by visiting professors.
data.notes: [Note: Topics and availability are subject to change.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in 18th- and 19th-Century Art
data.description: A seminar course that examines the Neoclassic and Romantic currents of art between 1750 and 1850.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Topics in First Nations' Visual Culture
data.description: A study of historical and contemporary aspects of First Nations' visual culture. The particular emphasis will vary according to the specialization and interests of the instructor.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in 20th-Century Art
data.description: A study of the major innovations in late modern and contemporary art. Honours Art History majors interested in late modern and especially contemporary art are encouraged to use this course as preparation for the fourth year course.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Painting
data.description: An advanced painting course with an emphasis on the student's individual development as a painter, through independent problems, along with class discussions and individual critiques.
data.prerequisites: FINE 220 or 221
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Painting Studio
data.description: This course is designed for students in the Honours Studio specialization. This course will prepare students for Fine 472 and Fine 473 and will involve intensive, experimental exploration and development of individual studio practice in painting, research into the work of related artists and critiques by faculty members, graduate students, visiting artists and fellow students.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3B and FINE 220, 221, 320, 324, 319
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Sculpture
data.description: An exploration of sculptural problems in a variety of mediums.
data.prerequisites: FINE 222 and one of FINE 223 or FINE 223A
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Sculpture Studio
data.description: This course is designed for students in the Honours Studio specialization. This course will prepare students for FINE 472 and FINE 473 and will involve intensive, experimental exploration and development of individual studio practice in sculpture, research into the work of related artists and critiques by faculty members, graduate students, visiting artists and fellow students.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3B and FINE 222, 223 or 223A, 322, 324, 319
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Drawing
data.description: An exploration of drawing problems in a variety of media. The emphasis is on students becoming familiar with contemporary approaches to drawing and developing their own individual expression.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Drawing Studio
data.description: This course is designed for students in the Honours Studio specialization. This course will prepare students for Fine 472 and Fine 473 and will involve intensive, experimental exploration and development of individual studio practice in drawing, research into the work of related artists and critiques by faculty members, graduate students, visiting artists and fellow students.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3B and FINE 224, 225, 324, 319
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Image-Making Through Printmaking Processes
data.description: For students interested in pursuing printmaking as their area of concentration in FINE 472 & 473. Students must have demonstrated an ability to work independently on individual printmaking projects. Work will be assessed by the Fine Arts faculty as a whole.
data.prerequisites: FINE 226A, 226B
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Printmaking Studio
data.description: This course is designed for students in the Honours Studio specialization. This course will prepare students for FINE 472 and FINE 473 and will involve intensive, experimental exploration and development of individual studio practice in printmaking, research into the work of related artists and critiques by faculty members, graduate students, visiting artists and fellow students.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3B and Fine 226A, 226B, 324, 326A, 319
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Electronic Imaging
data.description: Advanced Electronic Imaging builds on the technical and aesthetic ideas explored in FINE 229. Students are introduced to the principles of animation and audio-visual editing using 3-dimensional imaging and digital audio software. Through a series of structured assignments students will have the opportunity to develop a personal approach to the course content.
data.prerequisites: FINE 229
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Electronic Imaging Studio
data.description: This course is designed for students in the Honours Studio specialization. This course will prepare students for FINE 472 and FINE 473 and will involve intensive, experimental exploration and development of individual studio practice in electronic imaging, research into the work of related artists and critiques by faculty members, graduate students, visiting artists and fellow students.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3B; FINE 228/228D or 228H/229; and 319, 324, 328/328D
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: The study of art in context including visiting artists' lectures, gallery and museum exhibitions and field trips. Specific course content term-by-term will be structured around the schedule of events in the department and the region. Students will be required to prepare written reports and visual documents.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: See FINE 348A for course description.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: The study of art in context including visiting artists' lectures, gallery and museum exhibitions and field trips. Specific course content term-by-term will be structured around the schedule of events in the department and the region. Students will be required to prepare written reports and visual documents.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art in Context
data.description: See FINE 349A for course description.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Does not fulfil any Fine Arts major or minor plan requirements. Graded on a Credit/Fail basis.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in Film
data.description: Special topics will be announced from year to year.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Special Topics in Film
data.description: Special topics will be announced from year to year.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Ceramic Studio
data.description: This is an advanced studio course with an emphasis on the exploration and development of individual practice in the area of ceramics.
data.prerequisites: (FINE 222 or 223), FINE 272
data.notes: [Note: Studio course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Film Studies Seminar
data.description: An introduction to key aspects of motion picture and TV production, film preservation and restoration with visits to studios, film archives, and museums. Screening of selected films and discussions focusing on material unavailable in Canada. Meetings with scholars/students.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies course. Three weeks in Paris and London.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Film Studies Seminar
data.description: An introduction to key aspects of motion picture and TV production, film preservation and restoration with visits to studios, film archives, and museums. Screening of selected films and discussions focusing on material unavailable in Canada. Meetings with scholars/students.
data.notes: [Note: Film Studies course. Three weeks in Paris and London.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Selected Subjects in Fine Arts
data.description: Research and reading courses under the direction of individual instructors in either art history or film studies.
data.notes: [Note: This course may be taken only as an elective after a student has completed 15.0 units and has taken all the courses available in the area related to the independent course (i.e. in either art history or film studies).]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Selected Subjects in Fine Arts
data.description: Research and reading courses under the direction of individual instructors in either art history or film studies.
data.notes: [Note: This course may be taken only as an elective after a student has completed 15.0 units and has taken all the courses available in the area related to the independent course (i.e. either art history or film studies.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Selected Subjects in Fine Arts
data.description: Independent studio course under the direction of an individual instructor; graded by a committee of Fine Arts faculty members.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 3B Fine Arts students
data.notes: [Note: This course may be taken only as an elective after a student has completed 15.0 units and has taken all the courses available in the area related to the independent course (i.e. painting, drawing, printmaking, sculpture or electronic imaging courses).]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Fine Arts Abroad
data.description: Working in the field with landscape, cityscape, and monuments of art, students will employ a variety of media to develop techniques for visual reportage, documentation, note-taking, and journal-keeping. Individual aesthetic responses to a wide range of subject matter will be encouraged.
data.prerequisites: At least 75% in FINE 393
data.notes: [Note: Information about current offerings can be obtained from the Department.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior Honours Seminar
data.description: This course is intended for students enrolled in the Fine Arts Honours degree in Art History and Studio. Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on an advanced creative research project in Studio.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Admission is by portfolio review.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior Honours Seminar
data.description: This course is intended for students enrolled in the Fine Arts Honours degree in Art History and Studio. Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on an advanced research project in Art History.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior Honours Seminar - Joint Honours and Arts and Business
data.description: Each student will work on individual and assigned projects critiqued by visiting artists and supervising faculty and graded by the entire faculty.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. This course is required of all Joint Honours and Arts and Business students in the Fine Arts Studio specialization. Must be taken in the winter term of 4B]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Senior Studies in Art History
data.description: Each student will work under the direction of a Fine Arts faculty member on an advanced research project in art history. The course is evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts faculty members.
data.prerequisites: FINE 396; Honours Art History students.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Aspects of the Cinemas of the Americas
data.description: This course takes a historical and thematic approach to analyzing the history, context, and various practices of cinema in the Americas.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Computational Digital Art Studio
data.description: An upper-level studio course to create computational projects that function as art works and aesthetic experiences. Students will work in interdisciplinary teams to combine computer science principles with fine art technical and conceptual skills. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: FINE 229, FINE 257, CS 105, CS 106; one of CS 100, CS 200, CS 230; Level at least 3A

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Computational Digital Art Studio
data.description: An upper-level studio course to create computational projects that function as art works and aesthetic experiences. Students will work in interdisciplinary teams to combine computer science principles with fine art technical and conceptual skills. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: FINE 229, FINE 257, CS 105, CS 106; one of CS 100, CS 200, CS 230; Level at least 3A

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Art of the 18th Century in Europe
data.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the culture of eighteenth century Europe. Particular attention is paid to France and Britain but these countries are discussed within the wider context of Europe and, at times, much of the world. By looking at the art, artists, patrons and collectors, some of the issues that will be discussed include cosmopolitanism, nationalism, empire-building, "taste", consumerism and women in society.
data.prerequisites: Level at least 2B Fine Arts or History or by permission of instructor.
data.notes: [Note: Art History course]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Aspects of European Cinema
data.description: This course offers a wide-ranging set of approaches to historical, contextual, and practical topics in the history of European cinema production.

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Advanced Topics in Studio
data.description: This course provides Fine Arts students with an opportunity to study a range of advanced topics that will explore, expand, and refine personal areas of interest in studio practice. Advanced topics will be announced from term to term.
data.prerequisites: FINE 319; at least four 200-level FINE studio courses; Level at least 3A Fine Arts Studio students only. Fine Arts average at least 65%
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of six times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Studio/Seminar
data.description: This is an advanced Fine Arts studio course with an emphasis on development of the student's individual and independent research interests. Students will be guided by faculty through critiques as well as open forums.
data.prerequisites: At least three 300-level FINE studio courses; Level at least 3B Honours Fine Arts Studio students; Fine Arts average at least 75%
data.notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Concept and Research
data.description: This seminar and fieldwork course explores aspects of theory, art history, and visual culture that are relevant to each student's areas of interest and contemporary art practice. Gallery visits and artists' talks are components of this course.
data.prerequisites: FINE 319; Level at least 4A Honours Fine Arts Intensive Studio Specialization
data.notes: [Note: A course fee of $100 may be required.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Honours Concept and Research
data.description: This seminar course explores aspects of art theory, history, and visual culture that will assist students in situating their work within contemporary art practice.
data.prerequisites: FINE 319; Level at least 4A Honours Fine Arts Intensive Studio Specialization

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Intensive Studio Specialization 1
data.description: This course is for students who wish to be practicing artists and who are enrolled in the Intensive Studio Specialization. The course involves an intensive exploration and development of individual studio research through practice, resulting in the production of a significant body of work. Students will be guided by the work of relevant artists, as well as critiques by faculty members, graduate students, visiting artists, and fellow students. Submitted work will be evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts faculty.
data.prerequisites: FINE 308; At least 1.0 unit in 300-level FINE studio courses; a grade of 75% in each 300-level studio course; Level at least 4A Intensive Studio Specialization.
data.notes: [Note: Studio course. Admission by portfolio review.]

data.subject: FINE
data.title: Intensive Studio Specialization 2
data.description: This course is for students who wish to be practicing artists, and who are enrolled in the Intensive Studio Specialization plan. Students will develop strategies for independent studio research, and complete a body of work supported and complemented by appropriate documentation. Submitted studio work will be evaluated by a committee of Fine Arts Faculty.
